before_start: {"blocks":[{"key":"64jag","text":"Pork meat identification protocol. Meat Preparation protocol based on","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9sfee","text":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3550954/","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":53}],"data":{}},{"key":"f51bb","text":"\"About 500 mg of meat was triturated in pestle \u0026 mortar with four volumes (4 ml) of 0.2N NaOH. 5 μl of the extract was again mixed with eight volumes (40 μl) of 0.2N NaOH in a sterile micro centrifuge tube. Mix was heated at 75 °C in water bath for 20 min and then added eight volumes (360 μl) of 0.04 M Tris HCl (pH 7.75) for neutralization of pH. 1 μl of final mix containing about 100 ng DNA was used for.\"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"40133E177B5011EFA8380A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3550954"}}}}
description: {"blocks":[{"key":"9os5q","text":"Identifying species by identifying unique DNA sequences is common practice. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dsu9i","text":"In this case we will identify the presence or absence of pork DNA in a meat sample.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4pbar","text":"We will use the alkaline method for DNA extraction and LAMP method for DNA amplification and detection.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bjpa8","text":"This is not a new protocol but rather the detailing of a previously published protocol listed in the manuscript citation.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
disclaimer: {"blocks":[{"key":"d27sa","text":"This protocol is work in progress for now.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
materials_text: {"blocks":[{"key":"stnr","text":"Consumables: 3 x 1.5 ml Centrifuge tubes or equivalent, 1 PCR tube that matches the device well size to store the ready to be tested sample (aliquot).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"avi6r","text":"Devices: Pestle and mortar, LAMP/PCR/Water bath and thermometer, scale, pH meter, 1- 10 μl micropipette, 100- 1000 μl micropipette. Optional: Vortex.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ed3u4","text":"Reagents: NaOH, Tris, HCl, Dnase free water, meat to be tested","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

status.info: We are still developing and optimizing this protocol

steps.step: {"blocks":[{"key":"7gdh8","text":"Measure 500 mg pork meat without fat. This is our sample (aliquot.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"b15gi","text":"Measure 1 ml of the liquid meat and add it to a sterile centrifuge tube labeled \"raw sample\". This is done with a 100- 1000 μl micropipette.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"af3kc","text":"Prepare 5 ml of NaOH 0.2  mol/L (sodium hydroxide or caustic soda). This will be used twice, once 4 mL and once 40μL.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"72m8","text":"Add 4 ml from the  tube labelled \"NaOH 0.2 mol/L\" to the \"raw sample\" tube. This will break down the cell membranes freeing the DNA and also break down (denaturate) some of the proteins.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":76,"length":110}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bg4at","text":"Measure 5 μL from previous step and add it to a new sterile centrifuge tube labeled \"prepared sample\". This is done with a 1- 10 μl micropipette.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bfpmn","text":"Add in the \"prepared sample\" new tube 40μL from the  tube labelled \"NaOH 0.2 mol/L\".","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"bc6h4","text":"Heat the resulting mix at 75 Celsius for 20 minutes in a water bath or using the LAMP device or a PCR device. This will further break down the cell membranes freeing the DNA.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":110,"length":64}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"2ccv2","text":"Prepare (360 μl) of 0.04 mol/L Tris HCl (pH 7.75).","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3jgvn","text":"This will be done by mixing Tris with HCl","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"71alm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a071b","text":"MW for TRIS Hydrochloride (C4H11NO3 ·HCl) 157.6 mol/Liter



0.04 M TRIS TRIS Hydrochloride: m=CMV =0.04mol/L*157.6g/mol *360uL=2.26 mg of TRIS Hydrochloride

Normally we make half the solution and titrate with HCl ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":96,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b2g17","text":"https://www.reddit.com/r/labrats/comments/193ei6n/trying_to_prepare_trishcl_buffer_ph_seems/?rdt=42146

https://www.cshlpress.com/pdf/sample/2014/LabRefV1/LabRefV1Ch1S1.pdf has collection of reagents","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"24q09","text":"pH calculations= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=387t-nh0OMg","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":17,"length":43}],"data":{}},{"key":"5dd4o","text":"https://www.cusabio.com/m-296.html#a21 for calculating Tris HCL pH from Tris and Hydrocloric acid","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":38}],"data":{}},{"key":"7h26p","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"C1F775DE7B5811EF98B30A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=387t-nh0OMg"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"C1F776177B5811EF98B30A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.cusabio.com/m-296.html#a21"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"6dnbe","text":"In a new centrifuge tube labelled \"NaOH 0.2  mol/L\" add 5 mL DNAfree water and 40 mg or NaOH. Mix to dissolve manually or using a vortex.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"71ga1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bprus","text":"For general molarity calculations see Molarity calcualation","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":59}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":38,"length":21}],"data":{}},{"key":"a3nm1","text":"Molar concentration is the number of moles contained in one Liter of a substance. The concentration of a solution is expressed in mol/L.\t","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":137}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b4j34","text":"C=(m/M)/V where  V is the volume in liters m is mass in grams and M is molar weight? in grams/mol","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":97}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"feo54","text":"https://www.alloprof.qc.ca/en/students/vl/sciences/calculating-molar-concentration-s1622","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":88}],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":88}],"data":{}},{"key":"4rmjk","text":"----","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":4}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"eos3u","text":"Molecular Weight of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) =40 g/mol: Na=22.989g/mol O=15.999g/mol H=1.008g/mol (http://chembook.org/page-nonav.php?chnum=1§=5)   so: 22.989g/mol+15.999g/mol+1.008g/mol=39.996g/mol.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":198}],"entityRanges":[{"key":2,"offset":98,"length":46}],"data":{}},{"key":"cgnn4","text":" ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"bquaf","text":"so for us: m=C*M*V =0.2mol/L*40g/mol *5mL= 8 g/L*5 mL=40 mg of NaOH","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":67}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6dt4m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8E28E3F37B5411EF98B30A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://chem.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/Introductory_Chemistry/Introductory_Chemistry/13%3A_Solutions/13.06%3A_Specifying_Solution_Concentration-_Molarity#:~:text=The%20symbol%20for%20molarity%20is,the%20molarity%20of%20a%20substance"}},"1":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"93473C707B5611EF98B30A58A9FEAC02","url":"https://www.alloprof.qc.ca/en/students/vl/sciences/calculating-molar-concentration-s1622"}},"2":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"93473CA47B5611EF98B30A58A9FEAC02","url":"http://chembook.org/page-nonav.php?chnum=1\u0026sect=5)"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"c9g4h","text":"Add 360 μl of the 0.04 mol/L Tris HCl. This is done for for neutralization of pH.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
{"blocks":[{"key":"cfl58","text":"Sample 1 μl in a PCR tube and store at -20.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"61knm","text":"Grind (triturate) the meat in a pestle and mortar. This will break the structure and results in a paste/liquid.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

title: Meat identification protocol
warning: {"blocks":[{"key":"1boqi","text":"Use appropriate PPE and follow Safe Work Practices.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"62oid","text":"NaOH (sodium hydroxide or caustic soda) needs to be handled with gloves because it's a highly corrosive alkali.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"ce978","text":"Seek and follow Safety Data Sheets for NaOH and HCl","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
